abstracts.cdata!: In Madagascar, children across the country have been afflicted by a remarkably high rate of infection by various intestinal worms, which can cause anemia. A community-based response, supported by the World Bank, has brought action on several fronts, ranging from nutritional supplements to grants for school water tanks. In almost four years, SEECALINE a community nutrition program in Madagascar has treated 1.2 million students, preschoolers and non-enrolled school-aged children for intestinal parasites. The program has provided iron supplements to 800,000 students, funded 71 micro-projects, and trained 20,000 teachers. The program continues to tackle iodine deficiency - another prevalent, but easily remedied problem which causes mental retardation and poor growth in all children, and can cause younger children to become deaf. Iodine deficiency affects all children's capacity to learn.
